Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Story: I stared at the calendar on my phone, my thumb hovering over the RSVP for the family’s annual Lunar New Year dinner. My mother had already called twice, reminding me how important it was to be there, how my presence meant upholding our family’s traditions. I could almost hear her voice, gentle but firm, “It’s not just a meal, it’s who we are.” But as I scrolled through my emails, a reminder popped up for the national continuing education seminar—mandatory for pharmacists, scheduled for the same evening. Missing it would mean falling behind on the latest treatments, risking my license, and letting down my patients and colleagues. My heart pounded as I imagined my family’s disappointment if I didn’t show up, the empty seat at the table, the questions. At the same time, I pictured my supervisor’s raised eyebrow, the subtle judgment from peers if I missed the seminar. I felt torn, pulled in two directions by expectations I couldn’t ignore, wishing I could be in both places at once.
